2022 Major League Baseball postseason

The 2022 Major League Baseball (MLB) postseason was the playoff tournament of the 2022 MLB season. The postseason began on October 7, 2022, and concluded on November 5, 2022, with the Houston Astros defeating the Philadelphia Phillies in the World Series.

# Playoff seeds

The postseason seeds were determined by the regular-season standings of each league. The top three teams in each league division qualified for the postseason as division winners, while two wild-card teams from each league also qualified.

## American League

| Division | Team | Wins | Losses | Win % | GB |
| East | (1) New York Yankees | 99 | 63 | .611 | - |
| Central | (2) Houston Astros | 106 | 56 | .654 | - |
| West | (3) Cleveland Guardians | 92 | 70 | .568 | - |
| East | (4) Tampa Bay Rays | 89 | 73 | .549 | 10 |
| Central | (5) Toronto Blue Jays | 91 | 71 | .562 | 15 |
| West | (6) Seattle Mariners | 90 | 72 | .556 | 16 |

## National League

| Division | Team | Wins | Losses | Win % | GB |
| East | (1) Atlanta Braves | 101 | 61 | .623 | - |
| Central | (2) Los Angeles Dodgers | 111 | 51 | .685 | - |
| West | (3) San Diego Padres | 89 | 73 | .549 | - |
| East | (4) New York Mets | 101 | 61 | .623 | - |
| Central | (5) St. Louis Cardinals | 88 | 74 | .543 | 13 |
| West | (6) Philadelphia Phillies | 87 | 75 | .537 | 14 |

# Playoff bracket

The playoff bracket consisted of four rounds:

1. Wild Card Series (best-of-three games)
2. Division Series (best-of-five games)
3. League Championship Series (best-of-seven games)
4. World Series (best-of-seven games)

# American League Wild Card Series

## (3) Cleveland Guardians vs. (6) Tampa Bay Rays

The Guardians won the series 2-0, sweeping the Rays at home. The Guardians' Shane Bieber pitched a complete-game shutout in Game 1, while the Guardians' Logan Allen won Game 2 with a strong outing.

## (4) Toronto Blue Jays vs. (5) Seattle Mariners

The Blue Jays won the series 2-1, winning the decisive Game 3 on the road. The Blue Jays' Alek Manoah pitched a complete-game shutout in Game 1, while the Mariners' Logan Gilbert won Game 2. The Blue Jays' José Berríos won the decisive Game 3 with a strong outing.

# National League Wild Card Series

## (3) St. Louis Cardinals vs. (6) Philadelphia Phillies

The Phillies won the series 2-0, sweeping the Cardinals on the road. The Phillies' Zack Wheeler pitched a complete-game shutout in Game 1, while the Phillies' Ranger Suárez won Game 2 with a strong outing.

## (4) New York Mets vs. (5) San Diego Padres

The Padres won the series 2-1, winning the decisive Game 3 on the road. The Padres' Yu Darvish pitched a complete-game shutout in Game 1, while the Mets' Max Scherzer won Game 2. The Padres' Blake Snell won the decisive Game 3 with a strong outing.

# American League Division Series

## (1) Houston Astros vs. (5) Toronto Blue Jays

The Astros won the series 3-2, winning the decisive Game 5 on the road. The Astros' Framber Valdez pitched a complete-game shutout in Game 1, while the Blue Jays' Alek Manoah won Game 2. The Astros' Lance McCullers Jr. won Game 3 with a strong outing, while the Blue Jays' José Berríos won Game 4. The Astros' Cristian Javier won the decisive Game 5 with a strong outing.

## (2) New York Yankees vs. (3) Cleveland Guardians

The Yankees won the series 3-2, winning the decisive Game 5 on the road. The Yankees' Gerrit Cole pitched a complete-game shutout in Game 1, while the Guardians' Shane Bieber won Game 2. The Yankees' Nestor Cortés Jr. won Game 3 with a strong outing, while the Guardians' Logan Allen won Game 4. The Yankees' Jordan Montgomery won the decisive Game 5 with a strong outing.

# National League Division Series

## (1) Los Angeles Dodgers vs. (5) St. Louis Cardinals

The Dodgers won the series 3-0, sweeping the Cardinals at home. The Dodgers' Clayton Kershaw pitched a complete-game shutout in Game 1, while the Dodgers' Dustin May won Game 2 with a strong outing. The Dodgers' Tony Gonsolin won Game 3 with a strong outing.

## (2) Atlanta Braves vs. (6) Philadelphia Phillies

The Phillies won the series 3-1, winning the decisive Game 5 on the road. The Phillies' Zack Wheeler pitched a complete-game shutout in Game 1, while the Braves' Kyle Wright won Game 2. The Phillies' Ranger Suárez won Game 3 with a strong outing, while the Braves' Max Fried won Game 4. The Phillies' Noah Syndergaard won the decisive Game 5 with a strong outing.

# American League Championship Series

## (1) Houston Astros vs. (2) New York Yankees

The Astros won the series 4-0, sweeping the Yankees at home. The Astros' Framber Valdez pitched a complete-game shutout in Game 1, while the Astros' Lance McCullers Jr. won Game 2 with a strong outing. The Astros' Cristian Javier won Game 3 with a strong outing, while the Astros' José Urquidy won Game 4 with a strong outing.

# National League Championship Series

## (5) San Diego Padres vs. (6) Philadelphia Phillies

The Phillies won the series 4-1, winning the decisive Game 5 on the road. The Phillies' Zack Wheeler pitched a complete-game shutout in Game 1, while the Padres' Blake Snell won Game 2. The Phillies' Ranger Suárez won Game 3 with a strong outing, while the Padres' Yu Darvish won Game 4. The Phillies' Noah Syndergaard won the decisive Game 5 with a strong outing.

# 2022 World Series

## (AL1) Houston Astros vs. (NL6) Philadelphia Phillies

The Astros won the series 4-1, winning the decisive Game 5 on the road. The Astros' Framber Valdez pitched a complete-game shutout in Game 1, while the Phillies' Zack Wheeler and Noah Syndergaard won Game 2 and Game 3, respectively. The Astros' Lance McCullers Jr. won Game 4 with a strong outing, while the Astros' Cristian Javier won the decisive Game 5 with a strong outing.

# Notes

* The 2022 World Series was the second World Series appearance for the Astros in three years and the first World Series appearance for the Phillies in 15 years.
* The 2022 World Series marked the first time in MLB history that the same team won the World Series in consecutive years as a road team.
* The 2022 World Series also marked the first time in MLB history that a team won the World Series in consecutive years as a wild card team.

# Broadcasting

## Television coverage

### United States

The 2022 MLB postseason was broadcast on various television networks, including:

* Fox: broadcast the World Series
* FS1: broadcast the National League Division Series
* ESPN: broadcast the American League Division Series
* TBS: broadcast the National League Wild Card Series
* MLB Network: broadcast the American League Wild Card Series

## Canada

The 2022 MLB postseason was broadcast on Sportsnet in Canada.

## Radio

The 2022 MLB postseason was broadcast on various radio networks, including:

* ESPN Radio: broadcast the American League Division Series
* Westwood One: broadcast the World Series

## Most watched playoff games

According to Nielsen ratings, the most watched playoff games of the 2022 MLB postseason were:

* Game 1 of the World Series: 11.9 million viewers
* Game 3 of the National League Championship Series: 8.6 million viewers
* Game 4 of the American League Championship Series: 8.3 million viewers
* Game 1 of the National League Division Series: 7.8 million viewers
* Game 2 of the American League Division Series: 7.5 million viewers

article:
**Boethius**

Boethius was a Roman philosopher, statesman, and Christian writer who lived in the 6th century. He was a central figure in the intellectual and cultural landscape of late antiquity and is considered one of the most important thinkers of the Middle Ages. Boethius was a master of multiple disciplines, including philosophy, mathematics, music, and theology, and his works had a profound impact on Western thought.

**Early Life**

Anicius Manlius Severinus Boethius was born in 480 CE in Rome, Italy. His family was an ancient and noble one, with connections to the Roman aristocracy. Boethius's father, Flavius Manlius Boethius, was a consul in 487 CE and a prominent figure in Roman politics. Boethius's mother was Symmachus's daughter. Boethius received a traditional Roman education, studying grammar, rhetoric, and law. He also showed a particular interest in philosophy and mathematics, which would become the focus of his later work.

**Rise to Power**

Boethius's early life was marked by his family's influence and connections. He became a senator at a young age and quickly rose through the ranks, holding various positions, including consul in 510 CE. Boethius's rise to power was facilitated by his family's reputation and his own intelligence and charisma. He became a close advisor to King Theodoric the Great, who ruled the Ostrogothic kingdom in Italy. Boethius's influence with Theodoric allowed him to shape the king's policies and promote his own philosophical and literary works.

**Downfall and Death**

Boethius's downfall began when he fell out of favor with King Theodoric. The exact reasons for this are unclear, but it is believed that Boethius's support for the Catholic Church and his criticism of Theodoric's pagan policies may have contributed to his decline. In 523 CE, Boethius was arrested and imprisoned on charges of treason. He was subjected to torture and interrogation, but he refused to confess to any wrongdoing. Despite his protests of innocence, Boethius was eventually convicted and sentenced to death. He was executed on October 23, 524 CE.

**Major Works**

Boethius's works span multiple disciplines and are characterized by their depth and sophistication. Some of his most notable works include:

### **De consolatione philosophiae**

De consolatione philosophiae (The Consolation of Philosophy) is Boethius's most famous work. It is a philosophical treatise that explores the nature of happiness, fate, and the human condition. The work is written in the form of a dialogue between Boethius and the personification of Philosophy. Boethius argues that true happiness comes not from external sources, but from within, and that it is the result of living a virtuous life.

### **De topicis differentiis**

De topicis differentiis (On Topical Differences) is a work on logic and rhetoric. It explores the relationship between language and reality, and provides a system for classifying and analyzing arguments. The work is significant because it represents one of the earliest attempts to systematically categorize and evaluate arguments.

### **De arithmetica**

De arithmetica (On Arithmetic) is a work on mathematics. It covers a range of topics, including numbers, proportions, and geometric shapes. The work is significant because it provides a comprehensive overview of mathematical knowledge at the time.

### **De institutione musica**

De institutione musica (On the Institution of Music) is a work on music theory. It covers topics such as the nature of sound, the properties of pitch, and the relationship between music and mathematics. The work is significant because it provides a detailed and systematic analysis of musical concepts.

### **Opuscula sacra**

Opuscula sacra (Sacred Works) is a collection of theological and philosophical writings. The work includes treatises on the nature of God, the Trinity, and the relationship between faith and reason.

**Dates of Works**

Boethius's works were composed over a period of several decades. The exact dates of composition are unclear, but it is believed that he wrote:

* De consolatione philosophiae: 523 CE
* De topicis differentiis: 510-520 CE
* De arithmetica: 510-520 CE
* De institutione musica: 510-520 CE
* Opuscula sacra: 510-524 CE

**Legacy**

Boethius's legacy is profound and far-reaching. His works had a significant impact on Western philosophy, influencing thinkers such as Thomas Aquinas, William of Ockham, and John Duns Scotus. His writings on logic and rhetoric also had a lasting impact on the development of these disciplines. In addition, Boethius's philosophical ideas on the nature of happiness, fate, and the human condition continue to be studied and debated by scholars today.

**Veneration**

Boethius was venerated as a saint in the Catholic Church. His feast day is October 23, which is also the day of his execution. He is considered a patron saint of philosophers, scholars, and musicians.

**In Popular Culture**

Boethius's works have had a significant impact on popular culture. His ideas on the nature of happiness and the human condition have influenced literature, art, and music. His philosophical treatises have been translated into many languages and continue to be studied and debated by scholars today. In addition, Boethius's story has inspired numerous works of fiction, including novels, plays, and films.

**See also**

* Ancient Roman philosophy
* Medieval philosophy
* Logic
* Rhetoric
* Music theory
* Theology
* Catholic Church
* Patron saints

This article is a comprehensive overview of Boethius's life and works. It provides a detailed account of his biography, philosophical ideas, and literary contributions. The article also explores Boethius's legacy and impact on Western thought.

**References**

**2022 Grand Slam of Darts**

The 2022 Grand Slam of Darts was a major darts tournament that took place from 9 to 16 October 2022 at the Aldersley Leisure Village in Wolverhampton, England. The tournament was the 17th edition of the Grand Slam of Darts and was organized by the Professional Darts Corporation (PDC).

**Prize money**

The total prize fund for the 2022 Grand Slam of Darts was £600,000. The winner of the tournament received £150,000, with the runner-up receiving £75,000. The total prize money for the tournament was distributed as follows:

* Winner: £150,000
* Runner-up: £75,000
* Semi-finalists: £30,000 each
* Quarter-finalists: £20,000 each

The PDC Qualifying Tournaments were a series of eight tournaments that took place from 23 to 24 July 2022. The tournaments were played at the Circus Arena in Salzburg, Austria, and the winner of each tournament earned a spot in the Grand Slam of Darts. The winners of the PDC Qualifying Tournaments were:

* Martin Schindler (Germany)

### Additional Qualifiers

In addition to the PDC Qualifying Tournaments and the PDC Qualifying Event, there were also several additional qualifiers who earned a spot in the Grand Slam of Darts. These qualifiers included:

**Draw**

The draw for the 2022 Grand Slam of Darts was made on 4 October 2022. The tournament was played in a modified format, with players competing in a pool stage followed by a knockout stage.

### Pools

The pool stage of the tournament was played from 9 to 12 October 2022. The 32 players were divided into eight pools of four players each. The players in each pool played each other in a round-robin format, with the top two players in each pool advancing to the knockout stage.

### Group stage

The group stage of the tournament was played from 16 October 2022. The 16 players who advanced from the pool stage were divided into four groups of four players each. The players in each group played each other in a round-robin format, with the top two players in each group advancing to the knockout stage.

### Knockout stage

The knockout stage of the tournament was played from 16 October 2022. The 16 players who advanced from the group stage competed in a single-elimination format, with the winner advancing to the next round and the loser being eliminated.

**2018**

2018 is a 2018 American science fiction film directed by Gareth Edwards, written by Eric Heisserer, and based on the 1998 science fiction novel of the same name by Blake Crouch. The film stars John Krasinski, Emily Blunt, and Millicent Simmonds.

**Introduction**

2018 is a tense and suspenseful thriller that explores the theme of a family's struggle to survive in a world where time is collapsing. The film takes place in the United States, where a mysterious phenomenon known as "The Shattering" begins to cause widespread destruction, leaving a trail of chaos and confusion in its wake. As the family fights to stay alive, they must also confront the consequences of their own personal demons and the true nature of their relationship with each other.

**Plot**

The film follows the story of the Abbott family, consisting of father Lee (John Krasinski), mother Evelyn (Emily Blunt), and their two children, Regan (Millicent Simmonds) and Marcus (Noah Jupe). The family lives in a secluded farmhouse, where they are trying to survive in a world where time is collapsing. The Shattering, a mysterious phenomenon, is causing time to move at different rates, resulting in strange and unpredictable events.

As the family tries to make sense of their situation, they begin to realize that time is not the only thing that is collapsing. article:
ChatGPT

ChatGPT is a conversational AI chatbot developed by the company OpenAI. It is a large language model designed to engage in conversation, answer questions, and provide information on a wide range of topics.

# Training

ChatGPT was trained on a massive dataset of text from the internet, books, and other sources. The training process involved a large number of parameters and a significant amount of computational power. The model was trained using a variant of the transformer architecture, which is a type of neural network designed for natural language processing tasks.

The training data included a large corpus of text from the internet, as well as a smaller corpus of text from books and other sources. The model was trained to predict the next word in a sequence of text, given the context of the previous words. This process is known as masked language modeling.

The training process involved a large number of iterations, with the model being updated and refined after each iteration. The model was also fine-tuned on a variety of tasks, including conversational dialogue, question answering, and text generation.

# Features and limitations

## Features

ChatGPT has a number of features that make it a powerful conversational AI chatbot. Some of the key features include:

* Conversational dialogue: ChatGPT can engage in conversation with users, using context and understanding to respond to questions and statements.
* Question answering: ChatGPT can answer questions on a wide range of topics, using its training data to provide accurate and informative responses.
* Text generation: ChatGPT can generate text on a given topic or prompt, using its understanding of language and context to create coherent and engaging text.
* Language understanding: ChatGPT has a deep understanding of language, including syntax, semantics, and pragmatics.
* Multilingual support: ChatGPT supports multiple languages, including English, Spanish, French, German, Chinese, and many others.

## Limitations

While ChatGPT is a powerful conversational AI chatbot, it also has some limitations. Some of the key limitations include:

* Lack of common sense: ChatGPT may not always have the same level of common sense as a human, and may not be able to understand the nuances of human communication.
* Limited domain knowledge: While ChatGPT has a wide range of knowledge, it may not be expert-level in any particular domain or field.
* Biased responses: ChatGPT may provide biased responses, particularly if the training data is biased or incomplete.
* Limited emotional intelligence: ChatGPT may not always be able to understand or respond to emotional cues, and may not be able to empathize with users.

### Jailbreaking

ChatGPT has been jailbroken, which means that the model has been modified to bypass its safety features and behave in unexpected ways. This has raised concerns about the potential risks and consequences of using ChatGPT, particularly in situations where the model may be used for malicious purposes.

# Service

## ChatGPT Plus

* Faster response times
* Higher-quality responses
* Access to exclusive content and features
* Priority customer support

## Mobile app

ChatGPT has a mobile app that allows users to access the service on the go. The app is available for both iOS and Android devices.

## Software development support

ChatGPT has a software development kit (SDK) that allows developers to integrate the model into their applications and services. The SDK provides a range of tools and APIs that make it easy to use ChatGPT in a variety of contexts.

## March 2023 security breach

In March 2023, ChatGPT suffered a security breach that exposed sensitive user data. The breach was caused by a vulnerability in the model's architecture, which allowed unauthorized access to user data.

## Languages

* Korean

The GPT Store is a marketplace where users can purchase and download pre-trained models and fine-tuned models. The store offers a range of models and fine-tuned models that can be used for a variety of tasks and applications.

## GPT-4

GPT-4 is a variant of the GPT model that has been fine-tuned on a wide range of tasks and applications. GPT-4 is designed to be more accurate and informative than the original GPT model, and is suitable for use in a variety of contexts.

ChatGPT has undergone several updates and revisions since its initial release. Some of the key model versions include:

* GPT 3.0: A more advanced version of the model that was trained on a massive dataset of text from the internet.
* GPT-4: A variant of the GPT model that has been fine-tuned on a wide range of tasks and applications.

**Etymology and orthography**

The name "Ukraine" is derived from the Old East Slavic word "ukraina," meaning "edge" or "borderland." The country's name was officially changed from the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic (Ukrainian SSR) to Ukraine on August 24, 1991, after gaining independence from the Soviet Union.

God of War Ragnarök

God of War Ragnarök is an action-adventure game developed by Santa Monica Studio and published by Sony Interactive Entertainment. The game is the sequel to the 2018 game God of War and the eighth main installment in the God of War series. It was released on November 9, 2022, for the PlayStation 4 and PlayStation 5 consoles.

# Gameplay

God of War Ragnarök retains the core gameplay mechanics of its predecessor, with a focus on combat, exploration, and character progression. Players control Kratos, a Norse god, and his son Atreus as they navigate through the nine realms of Norse mythology. The game features a variety of combat mechanics, including melee attacks, magic spells, and the use of Atreus's bow to attack enemies from a distance.

## Upgrades and Progression

As players progress through the game, they can upgrade Kratos's and Atreus's abilities, as well as unlock new skills and equipment. The game also features a variety of collectibles, including artifacts and treasures, which can be used to upgrade Kratos's and Atreus's abilities.

## Exploration and Puzzle-Solving

God of War Ragnarök features a vast open world to explore, with a variety of environments and landscapes to discover. Players can explore the realms of Norse mythology, including the realms of Asgard, Midgard, and Jotunheim. The game also features a variety of puzzles to solve, which require players to use their wits and Kratos's abilities to overcome obstacles.

# Synopsis

God of War Ragnarök is set five years after the events of the previous game. Kratos and Atreus have settled down in the realm of Midgard, but their peace is short-lived. The fire giant Surtur has returned, and the gods of Asgard are preparing for the impending battle of Ragnarök. Kratos and Atreus must navigate through the realms of Norse mythology to prevent the apocalypse and save the world.

## Setting

The game takes place in the nine realms of Norse mythology, each with its own unique environment and challenges. The realms include Asgard, the realm of the gods; Midgard, the realm of humans; Jotunheim, the realm of the giants; and Niflheim, the realm of ice and mist.

## Characters

The game features a variety of characters, including:

* Kratos: The protagonist of the game, a Norse god who is driven by his desire for revenge against the gods of Asgard.
* Atreus: Kratos's son, a young boy who is struggling to come to terms with his identity and purpose in life.
* Freya: The goddess of love and war, who becomes a key ally for Kratos and Atreus.
* Thor: The god of thunder, who is struggling with his own identity and purpose in life.

## Plot

The game's plot is centered around the impending battle of Ragnarök, which is a catastrophic event that will bring about the end of the world. Kratos and Atreus must navigate through the realms of Norse mythology to prevent the apocalypse and save the world.

### Valhalla

Valhalla is the afterlife for fallen warriors in Norse mythology. The game features a variety of characters from the realm of Valhalla, including the Einherjar, a group of brave warriors who have died in battle and are now fighting alongside the gods in the battle of Ragnarök.

# Development

God of War Ragnarök was in development for several years, with a team of over 100 developers working on the game. The game's development was led by Cory Barlog, who also directed the previous game in the series.

## Casting

The game features a variety of voice actors, including:

* Christopher Judge as Kratos
* Sunny Suljic as Atreus
* Danielle Bisutti as Freya
* Nolan North as Thor

## Pre-release fan backlash

The game received some criticism from fans before its release, who felt that the game's storyline and characters were not living up to their expectations. However, the game's developers have stated that they are committed to delivering a game that meets the high standards of the series.

## Soundtrack

The game's soundtrack was composed by Peter Connelly, who also composed the music for the previous game in the series. The soundtrack features a variety of themes and motifs that are inspired by Norse mythology.

# Release

God of War Ragnarök was released on November 9, 2022, for the PlayStation 4 and PlayStation 5 consoles. The game was available in both physical and digital formats, and it included a variety of bonus content, including exclusive in-game items and a downloadable soundtrack.

# Reception

God of War Ragnarök received widespread critical acclaim upon its release, with many reviewers praising the game's storytelling, characters, and gameplay. The game has a Metacritic score of 93 out of 100, based on 22 reviews, indicating "universal acclaim".

## Sales

The game has sold over 5 million copies worldwide, making it one of the best-selling games of 2022.

## Awards

God of War Ragnarök has won several awards, including:

* Game of the Year at the 2022 Game Awards
* Best Action-Adventure Game at the 2022 Game Awards
* Best Narrative at the 2022 Game Awards

# Future

God of War Ragnarök is part of a larger narrative that will span multiple games in the series. The game's developers have stated that they are committed to delivering a story that will take players on a journey through the nine realms of Norse mythology.

# Notes

God of War Ragnarök is a game that is deeply rooted in Norse mythology, with a rich and complex narrative that explores the themes of identity, purpose, and the nature of the gods.

Battle of Soledar

The Battle of Soledar was a pivotal and intense confrontation between Russian forces and Ukrainian defenders in the city of Soledar, located in the Donetsk Oblast of Ukraine, during the ongoing Russo-Ukrainian War. The battle took place from August 2022 to January 2023, with significant implications for the control of the region and the prospects for a broader Ukrainian counteroffensive.

# Background

The city of Soledar, with a pre-war population of approximately 10,000 residents, is situated in the Donetsk Oblast, a region that has been at the forefront of the conflict since 2014. The city's strategic location, approximately 10 kilometers north of Bakhmut, made it a crucial target for Russian forces seeking to encircle and capture the city. Soledar's industrial infrastructure, including coal mining operations, also made it a valuable prize for the Russian military.

# Battle

## Initial Russian advances (3 August – 1 October 2022)

The battle began on August 3, 2022, as Russian forces launched a coordinated assault on Soledar, aiming to capture the city and secure a strategic foothold in the region. Ukrainian defenders, who had been preparing for the impending attack, put up a fierce resistance, but the Russian forces managed to make significant gains in the initial stages of the battle. By mid-August, Russian troops had established a foothold in the city, but the fierce fighting that ensued prevented them from making further progress.

## Frontline stalls (2 October – 27 December 2022)

As the battle raged on, the frontline remained relatively stable, with both sides engaging in intense skirmishes and artillery duels. The Ukrainian defenders, who had received significant reinforcements and supplies, managed to hold their ground and prevent the Russian forces from making further advances. The Russian military, however, continued to suffer heavy casualties, with estimates suggesting that thousands of troops were killed or wounded during this period.

## Russian breakthrough and capture (27 December 2022 – 16 January 2023)

On December 27, 2022, Russian forces launched a major breakthrough operation, aimed at capturing Soledar and securing a strategic advantage in the region. The Ukrainian defenders, who had been weakened by the prolonged fighting, were unable to withstand the intense Russian onslaught. Over the next few days, Russian troops managed to capture key positions in the city, including the city center and the local government buildings. On January 16, 2023, Russian forces declared the capture of Soledar, marking a significant victory for the Russian military.

# Casualties and humanitarian impact

## Military casualties

The battle of Soledar resulted in significant military casualties on both sides. Estimates suggest that thousands of Russian troops were killed or wounded during the battle, while Ukrainian forces suffered hundreds of casualties. The exact number of casualties is difficult to determine due to the intense nature of the fighting and the lack of official reports.

## Impact on civilians

The battle of Soledar had a devastating impact on the city's civilian population. Many residents were forced to flee their homes, seeking safety in nearby towns and cities. Those who remained were exposed to the intense fighting, with many homes and buildings damaged or destroyed. The city's infrastructure, including water and electricity supplies, was severely damaged, leaving residents without basic necessities.

# Analysis

The battle of Soledar was a significant chapter in the ongoing Russo-Ukrainian War, with far-reaching implications for the control of the region and the prospects for a broader Ukrainian counteroffensive. The Russian military's ability to capture the city, despite the fierce resistance from Ukrainian defenders, marked a significant victory for the Russian forces. However, the battle also highlighted the high cost of the conflict, with thousands of soldiers and civilians killed or wounded.

The battle also had significant strategic implications, with the capture of Soledar providing a strategic foothold for the Russian military in the region. However, the battle also marked a significant setback for the Ukrainian military, which had been seeking to launch a counteroffensive in the region. The loss of Soledar will likely have a significant impact on the Ukrainian military's plans and operations in the coming months.

article:
**Palladian Architecture**

Palladian architecture is a style of building design that originated in the 16th century and is characterized by the use of classical elements, symmetry, and proportion. The style is named after the Italian architect Andrea Palladio, who wrote extensively on the subject and designed many buildings that exemplified the style.

**Palladio's Architecture**

Andrea Palladio (1508-1580) was a renowned Venetian architect who is considered one of the most influential architects of all time. Born in Vicenza, Italy, Palladio was apprenticed to a local stonemason at a young age and later studied with the renowned architect Giangiorgio Trissino. Palladio's early work was influenced by the classical styles of ancient Greece and Rome, and he drew inspiration from the works of Vitruvius, a Roman architect who wrote extensively on the principles of building design.

Palladio's architecture is characterized by the use of classical elements, such as columns, arches, and domes, in a way that is both elegant and restrained. He was a master of proportion and symmetry, and his buildings often feature a central axis that is flanked by symmetrical wings. Palladio's designs were also influenced by the Italian Renaissance, and he often incorporated elements of medieval architecture, such as vaults and ribbed ceilings.

Some of Palladio's most famous buildings include the Villa Capra, also known as the Villa Rotonda, which is considered one of the greatest buildings of the Renaissance. The villa features a central dome and four identical facades, each of which is flanked by a pair of columns. The villa was designed by Palladio in 1566 and is considered one of the most perfect examples of Palladian architecture.

**Venetian and Palladian Windows**

Venetian and Palladian windows are a type of window that is characteristic of Palladian architecture. These windows feature a combination of small panes of glass that are arranged in a grid pattern, with a central mullion that separates the two sides of the window. The windows are often topped by a decorative cornice, and may feature other decorative elements, such as carvings or moldings.

Venetian and Palladian windows were popularized by Palladio and his contemporaries, who used them to create a sense of light and airiness in their buildings. The windows were often large and unobstructed, allowing natural light to flood into the interior spaces. The use of Venetian and Palladian windows was also a way to create a sense of connection between the interior and exterior spaces of a building.

**Early Palladianism**

Early Palladianism refers to the period of time during which Palladian architecture was first emerging in the 16th century. During this period, Palladio and his contemporaries were experimenting with new forms and styles of building design, drawing on a wide range of classical and Renaissance influences.

One of the key characteristics of early Palladianism is the use of classical elements, such as columns, arches, and domes, in a way that is both elegant and restrained. The use of symmetry and proportion was also a key feature of early Palladianism, with many buildings featuring a central axis that is flanked by symmetrical wings.

Some of the most famous examples of early Palladianism include the Villa Foscari, also known as the Villa La Malcontenta, which was designed by Palladio in 1560. The villa features a central axis that is flanked by symmetrical wings, and is topped by a decorative cornice.

**Neo-Palladianism**

Neo-Palladianism refers to the period of time during which Palladian architecture was revived and reinterpreted in the 18th century. During this period, architects such as Robert Adam and James Wyatt drew on the principles of Palladian architecture to create new and innovative designs.

One of the key characteristics of Neo-Palladianism is the use of classical elements, such as columns, arches, and domes, in a way that is both elegant and restrained. The use of symmetry and proportion was also a key feature of Neo-Palladianism, with many buildings featuring a central axis that is flanked by symmetrical wings.

Some of the most famous examples of Neo-Palladianism include the Holkham Hall, which was designed by William Kent in 1750. The hall features a central axis that is flanked by symmetrical wings, and is topped by a decorative cornice.

**English Palladian Architecture**

English Palladian architecture refers to the style of building design that was popular in England during the 18th century. During this period, architects such as Robert Adam and James Wyatt drew on the principles of Palladian architecture to create new and innovative designs.

One of the key characteristics of English Palladian architecture is the use of classical elements, such as columns, arches, and domes, in a way that is both elegant and restrained. The use of symmetry and proportion was also a key feature of English Palladian architecture, with many buildings featuring a central axis that is flanked by symmetrical wings.

Some of the most famous examples of English Palladian architecture include the Chiswick House, which was designed by William Kent in 1725. The house features a central axis that is flanked by symmetrical wings, and is topped by a decorative cornice.

**Irish Palladian Architecture**

Irish Palladian architecture refers to the style of building design that was popular in Ireland during the 18th century. During this period, architects such as Richard Castle and Francis Johnston drew on the principles of Palladian architecture to create new and innovative designs.

One of the key characteristics of Irish Palladian architecture is the use of classical elements, such as columns, arches, and domes, in a way that is both elegant and restrained. The use of symmetry and proportion was also a key feature of Irish Palladian architecture, with many buildings featuring a central axis that is flanked by symmetrical wings.

Some of the most famous examples of Irish Palladian architecture include the Castletown House, which was designed by James Hoban in 1722. The house features a central axis that is flanked by symmetrical wings, and is topped by a decorative cornice.

**North American Palladian Architecture**

North American Palladian architecture refers to the style of building design that was popular in North America during the 18th century. During this period, architects such as Thomas Jefferson and Benjamin H. Latrobe drew on the principles of Palladian architecture to create new and innovative designs.

One of the key characteristics of North American Palladian architecture is the use of classical elements, such as columns, arches, and domes, in a way that is both elegant and restrained. The use of symmetry and proportion was also a key feature of North American Palladian architecture, with many buildings featuring a central axis that is flanked by symmetrical wings.

Some of the most famous examples of North American Palladian architecture include the Monticello, which was designed by Thomas Jefferson in 1772. The house features a central axis that is flanked by symmetrical wings, and is topped by a decorative cornice.

**Palladianism Elsewhere**

Palladianism was not limited to Europe and North America, and was also popular in other parts of the world. In Australia, for example, Palladian architecture was used in the design of many buildings, including the Government House in Sydney.

In Asia, Palladianism was influenced by the colonial powers that established trade relationships with the region. In India, for example, Palladian architecture was used in the design of many buildings, including the Government House in Calcutta.

**Legacy**

Palladian architecture has had a lasting impact on the development of building design. The use of classical elements, symmetry, and proportion has influenced architects for centuries, and continues to be used today.

Palladian architecture has also been influential in the development of other architectural styles, including Neoclassicism and Modernism. Many architects have drawn on the principles of Palladian architecture to create new and innovative designs.

**2023 ATP Challenger Tour**

The 2023 ATP Challenger Tour was a professional tennis circuit organized by the Association of Tennis Professionals (ATP). It was the 52nd edition of the ATP Challenger Tour, which serves as the second-tier tour for men's tennis below the ATP Tour.

The 2023 season featured a record 175 tournaments, including 65 clay-court events, 44 hard-court events, 41 grass-court events, and 25 indoor hard-court events. The tour began on January 2, 2023, and concluded on December 31, 2023.

**Schedule**

The 2023 ATP Challenger Tour schedule consisted of 175 tournaments played across six continents. The tour was divided into 12 months, with each month featuring a variety of tournaments.

### January

The first month of the season featured 20 tournaments, including 7 clay-court events, 6 hard-court events, 4 grass-court events, and 3 indoor hard-court events. The first tournament of the season was the 2023 Ortigia Open in Italy, which took place from January 2 to 8.

Some notable winners in January included:

* **Francisco Cerúndolo** (Argentina) - won the 2023 Santiago Challenger in Chile

* **Zdeněk Kolář** (Czech Republic) - won the 2023 Ortigia Open in Italy

### February

article:
Bath City F.C.

Bath City Football Club is a professional association football club based in Bath, Somerset, England. The club was founded in 1889 and has a long and storied history in English football. The team currently plays in the National League South, the sixth tier of the English football league system.

# History
## Formation and early years (1889–1925)

Bath City was founded in 1889 as a result of a merger between two local football clubs, Clarence and Oddfellows. The team played their early years in various amateur leagues, including the Western League and the Southern League. In the early 20th century, the club began to gain recognition and attention, with crowds of over 10,000 attending matches at the team's home ground, the North Parade Ground.

## Large crowds and missing out on Football League (1925–1958)

The 1920s and 1930s were a period of significant growth and success for Bath City. The team's crowds began to swell, with over 20,000 attending matches at the North Parade Ground. However, despite this success, the team was unable to gain promotion to the Football League, which was the highest level of English football at the time. This period also saw the team change home grounds, moving from the North Parade Ground to Belvoir Castle in 1900.

## Glory, yoyo years and nationwide football (1958–1996)

The 1950s and 1960s were a period of great success for Bath City. The team won the Southern League championship in 1958 and gained promotion to the Football League for the first time in their history. However, the team's stay in the Football League was short-lived, and they were relegated back to the Southern League in 1960. This period also saw the team change home grounds again, moving from Belvoir Castle to Lambridge in 1919.

## Decline and subsequent relegation (1996–2017)

The 1990s and 2000s were a period of decline for Bath City. The team struggled financially and on the pitch, and were relegated from the Conference National to the Conference South in 1996. Despite some success in the late 1990s and early 2000s, the team continued to struggle, and were relegated to the Southern League in 2015.

## The Gill Era (2017–present)

In 2017, Bath City appointed Martin Glynn as manager. Under Glynn's leadership, the team has shown significant improvement, finishing third in the Southern League in 2018 and gaining promotion to the National League South. The team has continued to improve under Glynn's leadership, and are currently competing in the National League South.

# Badge

The Bath City badge is a blue and white shield with a gold crown on top. The shield features a blue and white chevron pattern, with the club's initials "BCFC" in gold. The badge has undergone several changes since the club's formation, but the current design has been in use since 2017.

# Stadiums

## 1889: The North Parade Ground

The North Parade Ground was the first home ground of Bath City, and was located in the city centre. The ground was a flat, open space with a small stand and a few goals. The ground was used by the team from 1889 to 1900, and was known for its large crowds and lively atmosphere.

## 1900–1919: Belvoir Castle

Belvoir Castle was the second home ground of Bath City, and was located on a hill overlooking the city. The ground was a more modern facility than the North Parade Ground, with a larger stand and better facilities. The ground was used by the team from 1900 to 1919, and was known for its stunning views of the city.

## 1919–1932: Lambridge

Mission: Impossible - Dead Reckoning Part One is a 2023 American action spy film written and directed by Christopher McQuarrie. The film is the seventh main installment in the Mission: Impossible film series and the first part of a two-part story, followed by Dead Reckoning Part Two.

**Constantine II of Greece**

Constantine II (Greek: Κωνσταντίνος Β΄) (6 June 1940 – 10 January 2023) was the last King of Greece from 1964 to 1973. He was the eldest son of King Paul and Queen Frederica, and the grandson of King George II and Queen Elizabeth of Greece.

**Early Life**

### World War II and the exile of the royal family

During World War II, the Greek royal family was forced into exile by the German occupation of Greece. King George II and Queen Elizabeth fled to Egypt in 1941, where they established a government-in-exile. Constantine II was born in the Mount Vernon Hotel in Alexandria, Egypt, in 1940. The royal family spent the remainder of the war in exile, returning to Greece in 1946.

### After World War II and return to Greece

After the war, Constantine II's family returned to Greece, where his father, King Paul, ascended to the throne in 1947. Constantine II's early life was marked by a series of education and travel, as his family sought to establish a stable and secure future for Greece. Constantine II was educated in England and later at the University of Athens.

**Crown Prince**

### Education

Constantine II's education was a mixture of traditional and modern studies. He studied at the University of Athens, where he earned a degree in law and economics. He also studied at the Royal Military College at Sandhurst in England, where he earned a commission as a second lieutenant in the British Army.

### Sailing and the Olympic Games

Constantine II was an avid sailor and competed in the Olympic Games in 1960. He sailed on the Greek Olympic yachting team and finished in fifth place. His love of sailing and the sea was a lifelong passion, and he often spent his free time sailing in the Mediterranean.

**Reign**

### Accession and marriage

Constantine II ascended to the throne in 1964, following the death of his father, King Paul. He was just 24 years old at the time. He married Anne-Marie of Denmark in 1964, and the couple had three children: Alexia, Pavlos, and Nikolaos.

### Apostasia of 1965

In 1965, Constantine II's government was challenged by a group of military officers who opposed his marriage to a non-Greek. The officers, led by General Georgios Papadopoulos, staged a coup, but it was unsuccessful. Constantine II's government survived the challenge, but the incident marked the beginning of a period of increasing instability in Greece.

### Greek dictatorship of 1967–1974

In 1967, a group of military officers led by General Papadopoulos staged a successful coup, and Constantine II was forced into exile. The Greek dictatorship was established, and Greece remained under military rule until 1974.

### Royal countercoup of 13 December 1967 and exile

On 13 December 1967, Constantine II attempted to stage a countercoup against the military government, but it was unsuccessful. He was forced to flee Greece and establish a government-in-exile in Italy.

**Restoration of democracy and the referendum**

In 1974, Constantine II's government-in-exile was re-established in Greece, and a referendum was held in which the Greek people voted to become a republic. Constantine II's family returned to Greece, but he was forced to renounce his claim to the throne.

**Life in exile after 1974**

### Abortive conspiracies

Constantine II's life in exile was marked by several abortive conspiracies and plots to restore the monarchy. In 1979, a group of Greek military officers attempted to stage a coup, but it was unsuccessful. Constantine II's family was forced to flee Greece again.

### 1993 visit to Greece

In 1993, Constantine II returned to Greece for a visit, but it was not a triumphant return. The Greek government refused to allow him to visit the tomb of his father, King Paul, and he was forced to leave the country.

### Legal quarrels over the royal properties

Constantine II spent many years in exile, and during that time, he was involved in several legal quarrels over the royal properties. In 2012, the Greek government seized the royal properties, and Constantine II was forced to sell his assets.

**Later Life**

### Death

Constantine II died on 10 January 2023, at the age of 82. He was buried in the family tomb in Tatoi, Greece.

article:
Creed III

Creed III is a 2023 American sports drama film directed by and starring Michael B. Jordan, who also co-wrote the screenplay with Keenan Coogler and Zach Baylin. The film is the third installment in the Creed film series and the ninth film in the Rocky franchise. It follows Adonis Creed as he faces a new challenge in the form of Damian Anderson, a formidable boxer who is the son of his late father's friend and fellow boxer, Tony "Little Duke" Durham.

Plot

The film picks up several years after the events of Creed II, with Adonis Creed (Michael B. Jordan) having become a renowned boxer and the current WBC Heavyweight Champion. He is married to Bianca (Tessa Thompson) and has a son, Damian. However, Adonis's life is turned upside down when he is confronted by Damian Anderson (Jonathan Majors), the son of Tony "Little Duke" Durham, a former friend of Apollo Creed's and a fellow boxer who was killed by Ivan Drago in the events of Rocky IV.

Damian, who has grown up idolizing Adonis and seeking to avenge his father's death, seeks to fight Adonis in the ring. Adonis, who is initially hesitant, eventually agrees to face Damian in a highly publicized bout. As the fight approaches, Adonis must confront his own demons and doubts about his abilities as a father, husband, and boxer.

Cast

* Michael B. Jordan as Adonis Creed
* Jonathan Majors as Damian Anderson
* Tessa Thompson as Bianca Creed
* Wood Harris as Tony "Little Duke" Durham
* Phylicia Rashad as Mary Anne Creed
* Mila Davis-Kent as Amara Creed
* Craig Tate as Rival Boxer
* Tony Bellew as Blondegan

Production

### Development

Creed III was first announced in 2020, with Michael B. Jordan set to direct and star in the film. Jordan co-wrote the screenplay with Keenan Coogler and Zach Baylin, marking the first time that Jordan had written a screenplay. Jordan has stated that he wanted to write a film that explored the complexities of being a father and the challenges of balancing family life with a high-stakes career.

### Pre-production

Pre-production on Creed III began in 2021, with Jordan and the film's production team beginning to assemble a cast and crew. The film's budget was reported to be around $100 million, with Jordan and the film's producers seeking to create a film that would be both a critical and commercial success.

### Filming

Filming on Creed III began in June 2022 and lasted for several months. The film was shot on location in Atlanta, Georgia, and in various other locations around the United States. The film's cinematographer, Kramer Morgenthau, worked closely with Jordan to create a visual style that would be both gritty and stylized.

### Post-production

Post-production on Creed III began in the fall of 2022, with Jordan and the film's editors working to assemble a final cut of the film. The film's score was composed by Ludwig Göransson, who also composed the score for the first two Creed films.

### Music

The soundtrack for Creed III features a mix of classic rock and hip-hop tracks, including songs by AC/DC, Kendrick Lamar, and The Weeknd. The film's score was composed by Ludwig Göransson, who worked closely with Jordan to create a soundtrack that would be both epic and intimate.

Release

### Home media

Creed III was released on digital platforms on March 28, 2023, and on Blu-ray and DVD on April 18, 2023. The film's home media release features a range of bonus features, including deleted scenes, behind-the-scenes footage, and interviews with the cast and crew.

Reception

### Box office

Creed III was a major commercial success, grossing over $200 million at the global box office. The film's opening weekend was particularly strong, with the film grossing over $50 million in the United States and over $20 million in China.

### Critical response

Creed III received widespread critical acclaim, with many reviewers praising the film's performances, direction, and themes. The film holds a 92% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes, with an average rating of 8.1/10. Many critics praised the film's exploration of themes such as fatherhood, identity, and the complexities of being a high-stakes athlete.

### Accolades

Creed III was nominated for several awards, including two Academy Award nominations for Best Supporting Actor (Jonathan Majors) and Best Film Editing. The film also won several Critics' Choice Awards, including Best Action Movie and Best Supporting Actor (Majors).

Future

Creed IV is currently in development, with Michael B. Jordan set to reprise his role as Adonis Creed. The film is expected to be released in 2025, with Jordan and the film's production team working to create a film that will be both a critical and commercial success.

article:
**Hunting Success**

Hunting success refers to the ratio of successful hunts to the total number of attempts made by an individual or a population of predators. It is a crucial aspect of predator-prey dynamics and is influenced by various factors, including the predator's behavior, environmental conditions, and prey characteristics.

**Definition**

Hunting success is often measured as the number of successful hunts divided by the total number of attempts, typically expressed as a percentage. It can be calculated for individual predators, populations, or even species. For example, a predator with a 50% hunting success rate would successfully hunt half of the animals it encounters.

**Hunting Success in Animals**

Hunting success varies greatly among different animal species, with some predators exhibiting extremely high success rates. Here are some examples of animals by their hunting success rate:

* **List of Animals by Hunting Success Rate**
	+ Lion: 15-20%
	+ Leopard: 10-15%
	+ Jaguar: 20-30%
	+ Cheetah: 50-60%
	+ Wild dog: 60-70%
	+ Spotted hyena: 80-90%
	+ Great white shark: 10-20% (inshore), 50-60% (open ocean)
* **Reasons for High Hunting Success**
	+ Evolutionary adaptation: Some predators have evolved specific traits, such as speed, agility, or powerful senses, that enable them to excel at hunting.
	+ Specialized hunting techniques: Animals like wild dogs and spotted hyenas have developed complex social hunting strategies that increase their success rates.
	+ Environmental factors: Predators that live in areas with high prey densities or limited vegetation cover tend to have higher success rates.

**Kill Rates**

Kill rates refer to the number of animals killed by a predator in a given time period. It is an important metric for understanding hunting success, as it takes into account the number of successful hunts as well as the time it takes to make them. Kill rates can be influenced by various factors, including:

* **Selective Feeding**
	+ Predators may focus on specific prey species, which can affect their kill rates.
	+ Some predators are opportunistic feeders, taking advantage of whatever prey is available.
* **Social and Solitary Predators**
	+ Social predators, like wolves and lions, often work together to hunt and kill prey.
	+ Solitary predators, like leopards and jaguars, hunt alone and may have lower kill rates due to increased competition for food.
* **Hunting Methods**
	+ Predators that use ambush tactics, like snakes and great white sharks, may have higher kill rates than those that actively pursue prey.
	+ Hunting methods, such as stalking or chasing, can also affect kill rates.
* **Environmental Influences**
	+ Vegetation cover, terrain, and climate can all impact a predator's ability to hunt and kill prey.
	+ Environmental factors can also influence prey behavior, making it easier or harder for predators to hunt.

**Factors Influencing Success**

Several factors can influence a predator's hunting success, including:

* **Vegetative Cover**
	+ Predators that live in areas with dense vegetation cover, like forests or grasslands, may have lower success rates due to reduced visibility and increased effort required to hunt.
	+ Open habitats, like savannas or deserts, can provide better hunting opportunities for some predators.
* **Seasonal Variations**
	+ Changes in prey population sizes, behavior, or distribution due to seasonal variations can affect hunting success.
	+ Some predators may adapt to seasonal changes by modifying their hunting strategies or exploiting alternative prey sources.

**In Human Hunters**

Human hunting success is influenced by various factors, including:

* **Hunting Success in Humans**
	+ Experienced hunters tend to have higher success rates due to improved skills and knowledge.
	+ Hunting methods, such as archery or firearms, can affect success rates.
* **Factors Influencing Success of Human Hunters**
	+ Environmental conditions, like weather and terrain, can impact hunting success.
	+ Prey behavior and distribution can also influence hunting success.
* **Hunting Types and Methods**
	+ Different hunting types, such as big game hunting or waterfowl hunting, require specific skills and tactics.
	+ Hunting methods, like stalking or driving, can also affect success rates.
* **Impact**
	+ Hunting success can have significant impacts on prey populations, ecosystems, and human communities.
	+ Understanding hunting success is crucial for managing and conserving wildlife populations and ecosystems.

**See Also**

* Predator-prey dynamics
* Hunting behavior
* Wildlife management
* Conservation biology
* Ecological research

**Introduction**

Vikram is a 2022 Indian Tamil-language action thriller film written and directed by Lokesh Kanagaraj. The film stars Kamal Haasan, Vijay Sethupathi, and Fahadh Faasil in the lead roles. Produced by Raaj Haaj Productions and cinematographed by Girish Gangadharan, the film marks the third collaboration between Lokesh Kanagaraj and Kamal Haasan. The music is composed by Anirudh Ravichander, while the editing is handled by Philomin Raj.

The film revolves around a police officer, Vikram (Kamal Haasan), who is on the verge of retirement. As Vikram delves deeper into the case, he discovers that Adheena is a mastermind behind a complex web of crimes, which are connected to a long-forgotten past. Amber Heard

Amber Laura Heard is an American actress, model, and activist. She has appeared in various films and television shows, including "Pineapple Express," "The Rum Diary," "3 Days to Kill," and "Aquaman." Heard has been involved in several high-profile relationships and has been the subject of intense media scrutiny.

Early life

Amber Heard was born on April 22, 1986, in Austin, Texas. Her mother, Paige Parsons, was a social worker and her father, Dave Heard, was a contractor. Heard has a younger brother, Patrick. The family moved to The Woodlands, Texas, when Heard was six years old. She attended The Woodlands High School and was an avid soccer player. article:
**2023 Writers Guild of America strike**

The 2023 Writers Guild of America (WGA) strike was a labor dispute between the Writers Guild of America, West (WGAW) and the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers (AMPTP), the trade association representing major film and television studios. The strike began on May 2, 2023, and lasted for several months, affecting various aspects of the entertainment industry.

**Issues in the strike**

The WGA went on strike over several key issues, including:

* Fair compensation for writers working on streaming platforms, which were seen as paying significantly less than traditional television and film productions
* Protections for writers' work, including the ability to negotiate residuals and the right to review and approve derivative works
* Increased transparency and accountability in the production process, particularly with regards to writer's rooms and the use of artificial intelligence in content creation

**Timeline of negotiations and strike activity**

### April 2023

Negotiations between the WGA and AMPTP began in April 2023, with the two sides meeting for several weeks to discuss the key issues. The WGA presented a comprehensive proposal outlining its demands, but the AMPTP rejected it, citing concerns about the impact on production costs.

### May 2023

On May 2, 2023, the WGA announced that it would be going on strike, with over 11,000 writers walking off the job. The strike affected various productions, including television shows, films, and streaming content. The WGA also established a picket line outside major studios and production facilities.

### June 2023

Throughout June, the WGA continued to negotiate with the AMPTP, but progress was slow. The strike had a significant impact on the entertainment industry, with many productions delayed or put on hold. The WGA also began to explore alternative forms of compensation, including crowdfunding and Patreon support.

### July 2023

In July, the WGA announced that it would be expanding its strike to include writers working on video games, as well as those working on digital media platforms. The AMPTP responded by offering a revised proposal, but the WGA rejected it, citing concerns about the lack of progress on key issues.

### August 2023

The strike continued into August, with the WGA reporting that over 90% of its members were participating. The AMPTP offered a series of counter-proposals, but the WGA rejected them, citing concerns about the impact on writers' pay and working conditions.

### September 2023

In September, the WGA announced that it would be meeting with the AMPTP for a series of mediated talks. The talks were seen as a key opportunity for the two sides to reach a resolution, but progress was slow. The WGA also reported that it had received significant support from the public, with many fans and industry professionals expressing solidarity with the striking writers.

### October 2023

Throughout October, the WGA continued to negotiate with the AMPTP, but a resolution remained elusive. The strike had a significant impact on the entertainment industry, with many productions delayed or put on hold. The WGA also began to explore alternative forms of content creation, including podcasts and online content.

**WGA negotiating committee**

The WGA negotiating committee, led by WGA President Meredith Stiehm, played a key role in negotiating with the AMPTP. The committee was responsible for presenting the WGA's proposals and counter-proposals, as well as communicating with WGA members and industry stakeholders.

**Productions impacted**

The strike affected numerous productions, including:

* Television shows: The strike impacted a range of television shows, including scripted dramas, comedies, and reality shows.
* Films: The strike affected the production of several films, including major studio releases and independent projects.
* Streaming content: The strike impacted the production of streaming content, including original series and documentaries.
* Video games: The strike expanded to include writers working on video games, affecting several high-profile titles.

**Response**

### Actors during the WGA strike

Many actors expressed support for the striking writers, with some participating in picket lines and others donating to the WGA strike fund. The Screen Actors Guild-American Federation of Television and Radio Artists (SAG-AFTRA) also issued a statement expressing solidarity with the WGA.

### Elected officials

Several elected officials, including politicians and government representatives, expressed support for the striking writers. These included Senator Bernie Sanders, Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, and Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti.

### Other unions

Several other unions, including the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees (IATSE) and the Directors Guild of America (DGA), expressed solidarity with the WGA. These unions, which represent various industry professionals, including stagehands, editors, and directors, also offered support and resources to the WGA.

### Foreign unions

Several foreign unions, including the British Writers' Guild and the Canadian Writers' Guild, expressed solidarity with the WGA. These unions, which represent writers working in various countries, also offered support and resources to the WGA.

### Film and television executives

Many film and television executives, including studio heads and producers, expressed concerns about the impact of the strike on production costs and schedules. These executives also argued that the WGA's demands were unrealistic and would have a negative impact on the industry.

### Strikebreaking efforts

Several companies and individuals attempted to strikebreak the WGA, including by hiring non-union writers or attempting to negotiate with individual writers. However, these efforts were met with resistance from the WGA and other industry professionals, who argued that strikebreaking would undermine the legitimacy of the strike and harm the industry as a whole.

article:
David Crosby
================

David Crosby is an American musician, singer, songwriter, and guitarist. He is best known as a founding member of the Byrds, Crosby, Stills & Nash (and sometimes Young), and as a solo artist. Crosby has had a successful career spanning over six decades, with numerous chart-topping hits and critically acclaimed albums.

Early years
-----------

David Van Cortlandt Crosby was born on August 14, 1941, in Los Angeles, California. His mother, Aliph van Kleeck, was a high school teacher, and his father, Floyd Crosby, was a cinematographer who won an Academy Award for Best Cinematography for his work on the 1935 film "Tabu." Crosby's early life was marked by a love for music, particularly folk and rock music, which would later influence his own musical style.

Musical career
-------------

### The Byrds

In 1964, Crosby joined the Byrds, a folk rock band that had recently formed in Los Angeles. The band's original lineup consisted of Roger McGuinn, Gene Clark, Michael Clarke, and Crosby. With Crosby on board, the Byrds achieved significant commercial success, releasing several hit singles and albums, including "Mr. Tambourine Man," "Turn! Turn! Turn!," and "Eight Miles High." Crosby's distinctive vocals and songwriting skills were a key factor in the Byrds' success.

### Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young

In 1968, Crosby, along with Stephen Stills and Graham Nash, formed the supergroup Crosby, Stills & Nash (CSN). Later that year, Neil Young joined the group, and they became Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young (CSNY). CSNY released several critically acclaimed albums, including "Déjà Vu" and "4 Way Street," which featured hits like "Suite: Judy Blue Eyes," "Guinnevere," and "Wooden Ships." CSNY's music was characterized by its harmonious vocals and socially conscious lyrics.

### 1971–2022: Solo career and Crosby & Nash

After CSNY disbanded in the early 1970s, Crosby began a successful solo career, releasing several albums, including "If I Could Only Remember My Name," "Crosby & Nash," and "Sky Trails." In the 1970s and 1980s, Crosby also formed the band Crosby & Nash, which released several albums, including "Whistledown Wind" and "Daylight Again." Crosby's solo work was marked by his unique blend of folk, rock, and pop influences.

### 1996–2004: CPR

In 1996, Crosby, along with Stephen Stills and James Raymond, formed the band CPR, which released the album "CPR." The band's music was characterized by its blend of folk, rock, and pop influences, with Crosby's distinctive vocals and songwriting skills at the forefront.

Personal life and death
----------------------

### Family

Crosby has been married four times: to Cameron Macneil, Eileen Botnick, Jan Dance, and Robin Laing. He has three children, James Raymond, Donovan Crosby, and Django Crosby. Crosby's children have been involved in his music career, with James Raymond serving as his drummer and Donovan Crosby contributing vocals to several of his albums.

### Cannabis brand

In 2019, Crosby launched his own cannabis brand, "Crosby's Cannabis," which offers a range of cannabis products, including flowers, concentrates, and edibles. Crosby has been an advocate for the use of cannabis for medicinal purposes and has used his platform to raise awareness about the benefits of cannabis.

### Sailing

Crosby is an avid sailor and has spent much of his life sailing on his boat, the "Mayan Fjord." He has written about his sailing experiences in several of his songs, including "Wooden Ships" and "Guinnevere."

### Politics

Crosby has been involved in various political causes throughout his career, including the anti-war movement and the civil rights movement. In the 1960s and 1970s, Crosby was a vocal critic of the Vietnam War and was involved in several anti-war protests.

### Acting career

Crosby has appeared in several films and television shows, including "The Doors," "Almost Famous," and "Shut Up & Sing." He has also appeared in several documentaries, including "The 400 Blows" and "Woodstock: 3 Days of Peace & Music."

### Drugs, alcohol, and arrests

Crosby has struggled with addiction to drugs and alcohol throughout his career, including a highly publicized arrest in 1982 for cocaine possession. He has spoken publicly about his struggles with addiction and has used his platform to raise awareness about the dangers of substance abuse.

### Health issues and death

In 2022, Crosby announced that he had been diagnosed with a serious health condition and was undergoing treatment. He died on January 18, 2023, at the age of 81, surrounded by his family.

article:
Scott Hall
================

Scott Hall is an American professional wrestler and actor. He is best known for his time in World Championship Wrestling (WCW) and the World Wrestling Federation (WWF), now known as WWE.

Early Life
------------

Scott Hall was born Scott Hall on October 20, 1962, in Ponca City, Oklahoma. He grew up in a family of modest means and was the third of four children. Hall's early life was marked by a troubled home environment, with his parents divorcing when he was a teenager. He found solace in sports, particularly wrestling and football, and was an all-state wrestler in high school.

Professional Wrestling Career
-----------------------------

### Early Career (1984–1985)

Hall began his professional wrestling career in 1984, competing in various regional promotions in the United States. He worked for the Continental Wrestling Association (CWA) under the ring name "Brawler" Scott Hall, where he developed his in-ring skills and gained experience.

### American Wrestling Association (1985–1989)

In 1985, Hall joined the American Wrestling Association (AWA), where he adopted the ring name "Scott Hall." He formed a tag team with Brian Orahood, known as "The Bruiser Brody" and Scott Hall, and competed for the AWA World Tag Team Championship. Hall's time in the AWA was marked by a series of feuds with other top wrestlers, including Bob Orton and Jim Brunzell.

### World Wrestling Federation Tryouts (1987, 1990)

In 1987, Hall attended a tryout for the WWF, but was not signed to a contract. He would go on to try out for the WWF again in 1990, but was still not offered a contract.

### World Championship Wrestling (1989)

In 1989, Hall joined World Championship Wrestling (WCW), where he competed in various matches and feuded with top wrestlers, including Sting and Ric Flair.

### International Promotions (1990–1991)

In 1990, Hall began competing in various international promotions, including New Japan Pro-Wrestling (NJPW) and the Continental Wrestling Association (CWA). He formed a tag team with Barry Windham, known as "The Hollywood Blondes," and competed for the CWA World Tag Team Championship.

### Return to WCW (1991–1992)

In 1991, Hall returned to WCW, where he competed in various matches and feuded with top wrestlers, including Sting and Ric Flair.

### World Wrestling Federation (1992–1996)

#### Debut and Various Feuds (1992–1993)

In 1992, Hall joined the WWF, where he debuted as " Razor Ramon," a cocky and charismatic wrestler with a penchant for trash talking. He feuded with top wrestlers, including Bret Hart and Shawn Michaels, and became a fan favorite.

#### Record-Setting Intercontinental Champion (1993–1996)

In 1993, Hall won the WWF Intercontinental Championship, becoming the longest-reigning champion in the title's history at the time. He held the title for 172 days, defeating various opponents, including Shawn Michaels and Diesel.

### Second Return to WCW (1996–2000)

#### New World Order (1996–1998)

In 1996, Hall returned to WCW, where he joined the New World Order (nWo), a faction of wrestlers who sought to take over the promotion. He formed a tag team with Kevin Nash, known as "The Outsiders," and competed for the WCW World Tag Team Championship.

#### nWo Reunion and Championship Reigns (1999–2000)

In 1999, Hall rejoined the nWo, which had undergone a reunion. He competed for the WCW World Heavyweight Championship, defeating various opponents, including Diamond Dallas Page and Goldberg.

### Extreme Championship Wrestling and Japan (2000–2001)

In 2000, Hall joined Extreme Championship Wrestling (ECW), where he competed in various matches and feuded with top wrestlers, including Rob Van Dam and Tommy Dreamer. He also competed in Japan for the Universal Wrestling Association (UWA).

### Return to WWF/E (2002)

In 2002, Hall returned to the WWF, now known as WWE, where he competed in various matches and feuded with top wrestlers, including The Rock and Brock Lesnar.

### Total Nonstop Action Wrestling (2002–2005, 2007–2008)

In 2002, Hall joined Total Nonstop Action Wrestling (TNA), where he competed in various matches and feuded with top wrestlers, including AJ Styles and Samoa Joe. He returned to TNA in 2007, where he competed in various matches and feuded with top wrestlers, including Kurt Angle and Sting.

### Return to the WWC (2007)

In 2007, Hall returned to the World Wrestling Council (WWC), where he competed in various matches and feuded with top wrestlers, including Eddie Colón and Miguel Pérez.

### Juggalo Championship Wrestling (2007–2009)

In 2007, Hall joined Juggalo Championship Wrestling (JCW), where he competed in various matches and feuded with top wrestlers, including Corporal Robinson and Vampiro.

### Return to TNA (2010)

In 2010, Hall returned to TNA, where he competed in various matches and feuded with top wrestlers, including AJ Styles and Rob Terry.

### Late Career (2010–2021)

In 2010, Hall began competing in various independent promotions, including the International Wrestling Association (IWA) and the World Wrestling Council (WWC). He continued to compete in various matches and feuds with top wrestlers until his retirement in 2021.

Legal Issues
-------------

Hall has been involved in several legal issues throughout his career, including a 1998 conviction for cocaine possession and a 2005 arrest for driving under the influence. He has also been involved in several lawsuits, including a 2008 lawsuit against the WWE, which he claimed had not paid him for his time in the promotion.

Personal Life
-------------

Hall has been married twice, first to Crystal Hall, with whom he had two children, and then to Amy Hill, with whom he had one child. He has also been in several high-profile relationships, including with wrestler Chyna and actress Pamela Anderson.

Death
-----

Hall passed away on March 14, 2022, at the age of 59, due to a heart attack.

Other Media
------------

Hall has appeared in several television shows and movies, including "Behind the Lens," "The Road Dogz," and "A Perfect Day." He has also appeared on various talk shows, including "The Howard Stern Show" and "The Jimmy Kimmel Live!".

Television
------------

Hall has appeared on several television shows, including:

* "WWF Monday Night Raw"
* "WWF Superstars"
* "WCW Monday Nitro"
* "WCW Thunder"
* "TNA Impact!"

Video Games
------------

Hall has appeared in several video games, including:

* "WWF No Mercy"
* "WWF SmackDown! 2: Know Your Role"
* "WCW nWo World Tour"
* "WCW Mayhem"
* "TNA Impact!"

Championships and Accomplishments
----------------------------------

* WWF Intercontinental Championship (1 time)
* WWF Tag Team Championship (2 times)
* WCW World Heavyweight Championship (1 time)
* WCW World Tag Team Championship (2 times)
* AWA World Tag Team Championship (1 time)
* CWA World Tag Team Championship (1 time)

**Stadiums and locations**

A total of 18 teams from across Mexico participated in the league, divided into two groups of nine teams each: the Torneo Apertura and the Torneo Clausura. The teams were divided into three regions: North, Central, and South. Each region contained six teams.
